size_and_shape.description: This section describes how the size and shape of the drug affect its disintegration and can be used to identify the drug.

examples.description: Small round tablets usually dissolve faster and exhibit a rapid color change.
Large oval capsules tend to take longer to dissolve, and their disintegration can be slower.
Film-coated tablets dissolve more slowly due to the coating, often resulting in gradual color change in the solution.

solution_transparency.description: This section describes how the transparency of the solution changes as the drug dissolves and how this can be used to identify the drug.

examples.description: Aspirin typically causes the solution to become slightly turbid as it dissolves, with a faint white cloudiness.
Paracetamol dissolves to form a clear solution, with minimal to no turbidity.
Ibuprofen dissolution results in a cloudy solution, indicating partial solubility and slower disintegration.
